channel.title: Codex - Sunlight Miscellany
channel.description:
It’s the first official Gauntlet Forum Miscellany! Woo! This one’s for Codex - Sunlight and titled “Three Dozen Strange Plants and Their Uses.”
Submissions need to be a single sentence, or 2-3 short sentences. By submitting here, you're agreeing to let us use it (you'll get a credit on the issue). We’re looking for evocative things; the purpose of the miscellany is to inspire the reader.
Here are some examples:
“The sturdiest ropes are made of Witch’s Lace, a distinctive ruffled, holey seaweed, but only the most dedicated—or desperate—adventurers choose to carry it and its unshakeable scent of low-tide rot.”
“Bone violets are pale, crinkled mushrooms with what might charitably be called a delicate flavor above ground. In the almost entirely fungal diet common below, however, they’re a confectioner’s staple, prized for sweetness and an almost floral flavor.”
“Crowcherries are small, bitter, and the main ingredient in a liqueur popular with a certain morbid set. The stories that a crowcherry tree will only bloom when fed with blood are almost certainly marketing drivel.”
P.S. If you want to be credited as something other than your forum name, let me know! (DMs or Slack messages are fine for that, but please keep submissions in this thread.)

-Marcin’s Cattails found on Linda 5JY3 sway in the gentle waves along many riverbanks generating electricity and storing in the fluffy tips to be discharged when the cattail is endangered. The locals have learned to safely harvest them to be used at stun batons.

-The Whispering Willows found the deepest hearts of the elven forests are known to speak truths yet to come true. Travelers who rest beneath their serene branchs will hear many strange things that could give them a clue in the future if they listen.

Seaborn’s Alluring Orchid has a unique pollination method: If you wander alone in the swamp, you may catch a sight of someone you love, entering a strange, green-walled tunnel. If you follow, they will stay always out of reach, until you reach the end of the tunnel. As you emerge from the tunnel, your love will vanish, leaving you blinking in the daylight, confused and covered in pollen.

Of course, there are off-brand dice with more or less obvious faults, but the best of these are the Icewarm dice - if your hand is cold, they roll low, if your hand is hot, they roll high. item.dc:creator: @yoshi
item.description:
@yoshi wrote:

Lepuflore is a rapid growing starchy tuber with a soft fluffy blooming flower. It can grow from a thumb sized cutting to a root the size a large rabbit in a few days. It draws out the nutrients and the soil will need to be left fallow for a season or two. Be careful where you discard cuttings, but is is a staple crop of nomadic folks who never stay in one place too long.

item.dc:creator: @DavidMorrison
item.description:
@DavidMorrison wrote:

Chased-in-the-Bower (Sometimes inaccurately recorded as Chaste-in-the-Bower) is a climber that grows in forest clearings. It sports large, soft pink flowers with a heady aroma, though it is more known for its foliage. It grows a dense mat of leaves that form “curtains” between tree-trunks, and a surprisingly comfortable covering to the forest floor. In the springtime it is common for the local youths to wear the blooms, to the knowing grins of their elders.

item.dc:creator: @Haladir
item.description:
@Haladir wrote:

A sign that a world had once been colonized by Terrans is the presence of low-growing yellow flowers with saw-toothed leaves. This green plant thrives on nearly any planet with liquid water, gaseous carbon dioxide, and silicate soil. The ubiquity of this species on so many worlds may be due the irrestibility of gently blowing off the “head” of its ripened, wind-borne seeds.

item.dc:creator: @Haladir
item.description:
@Haladir wrote:

Found only deep underground, the psychic Darkflowers appear as beautiful jet-black roses on writhing, thorny, pale white stalks. According to legend, the juice from their taproot can cure all ailments. A Darkflower will not allow its root to be taken, but a persuasive telepath might be able to convince one to give up some root willingly.

[Note: Based on a monster I designed for AD&D, which was published in a local fanzine back in 1991.]

item.dc:creator: @DavidMorrison
item.description:
@DavidMorrison wrote:

Maryland Creeper is a less well-known member of the genus Parthenocissus. Like its more famous cousin, it is a fast-growing climbing vine. The key difference is that it has a migratory root, and as such the plant itself can slowly but steadily travel as well as climb walls. The name has also been applied to the subject of a series of unsolved stranglings.
